title: How is the Cold War different from a conventional war? - Quora

response.answer_text: Cold War is a name of political confrontation of two superpowers that emerged after World War II, and while it was violent at times in proxy wars, Cold War itself was way far from the real war, it was more like mutual “GRRR”-ing. The main difference from a conventional war was that while winning battles (or proxy wars), there is no way to win or lose Cold war.

A cold war is one where each side attempts to create allies based on way of life, political theory. It can be extremely competitive with everything from sporting events, to space programs are used to sho one’s superiority to the other side. It is an ideological struggle with wars being fought by proxy nations. It is the ultimate zero sum game.

With the prospect of nuclear annihilation, the Cold War was only fought in proxy form in peripheral nations: Angola, Cambodia, Congo, Chile, Cuba, El Salvador, Greece, Indonesia, Korea, Laos, VietNam. It also involved much competition in non-military and quasi-military spheres: the Space Race, propaganda in print and by radio, economic growth, and even education systems.

Hot War is when two sides are shooting at each other because of disagreements. Cold War is when they have the disagreements but neither side wants to escalate it to shooting. The threat, spoken or unspoken, of possibly escalating it is part of the bargaining and posturing during Cold War.
